title: Awareness and perspectives of audiologists on assessment and management of misophonia in India
abstract: Background - The assessment and management of misophonia need a team approach, and audiologists are essential team members. However, the role of an audiologist in this condition is not well understood, and there is a lack of awareness even among professionals about their role in the assessment and management of misophonia. Purpose - The main aim of our study is to document the present level of awareness and knowledge about misophonia assessment and management among audiologists in India. Methods - A descriptive cross-sectional study was carried out among audiologists from all over India. Descriptive statistical procedures were measured based on the type of questions being addressed, and a non-parametric chi-square test was done to see the association among variables. Results - The results show a lack of knowledge about misophonia even among audiologists, as only 15.3% of the audiologist reported being confident in handling cases with misophonia. Conclusion - Although the exact assessment and management of misophonia is still the topic of debate, it is clear that audiologists are the team's key members. However, the results clearly show a lack of confidence in handling cases of misophonia among audiologists in India. This result shows the future need for Research in misophonia from an audiological perspective.

AWARENESS AND PERSPECTIVES OF AUDIOLOGISTS ON ASSESSMENT AND 1 
MANAGEMENT OF MISOPHONIA IN INDIA  2 
ABSTRACT:  3 
Background  4 
The assessment and management of misophonia need a team approach, and audiologists are 5 
essential team members. However, the role of an audiologist in this condition is not well 6 
understood, and there is a lack of awareness even among professionals about the ir role in the 7 
assessment and management of misophonia.  8 
Purpose  9 
The main aim of our study is to document the present level of awareness and knowledge about 10 
misophonia assessment and management among audiologists in India.  11 
Methods  12 
A descriptive cross -sectional study was carried out among audiologists from all over India. 13 
Descriptive statistical procedures were measured based on the type of questions being addressed, 14 
and a non -parametric chi -square test was done to see the association among variables.  15 
Resu lts 16 
The results show a lack of knowledge about misophonia even among audiologists, as only 15.3% 17 
of the audiologist reported being confident in handling cases with misophonia.  18 
Conclusion  19 
Although the exact assessment and management of misophonia is still the topic of debate, it is 20 
clear that audiologists are the team's key members. However, the results clearly show a lack of 21 
confidence in handling cases of misophonia among audiologists in India. This result shows the 22 
future need for Research in misophonia from an audiological perspective.  23 
Key Words : Misophonia; Awareness; Audiologists; Viewpoint; Assessment and Management  24 
INTRODUCTION  25 
Journal Pre-proof

The recent consensus definition has explained misophonia as a disorder that is characterized by 26 
decreased tolerance to speci fic sound stimuli (Swedo et al., 2022) . These specific sound stimuli 27 
are known as a trigger that causes various emotional and physiological responses, including an 28 
accelerated heart rate, sweating, anxiety, rage, irritability, and disgust. This disorder is  poorly 29 
understood and less explored in the medical field. However, disorders can significantly impair an 30 
individual's quality of life. In the field of psychology, it is regarded as a psychiatric disorder and 31 
treated accordingly. Schröder et al. ( 2013)  gave the diagnostic criteria stating misophonia as a 32 
psychiatric disorder. However, misophonia is a disorder that borders audiology, psychiatry, and 33 
the neurology field (Schröder et al., 2013) . 34 
Within the last two decades, there has been growing interest in the field of misophonia in 35 
developing diagnostic criteria (Brout et al., 2018) . Researchers have explained the disorder using 36 
psychiatric criteria (Schröder et al., 2013) . Misophonia can occur  with neurological and psychiatric 37 
disorders, but it is not limited to mood disorders, anxiety disorders, sensory processing disorders 38 
(SPD), and Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD). In audiology, misophonia is categorized with other 39 
sound disorders, including  tinnitus, hyperacusis, and phonophobia.  40 
Tinnitus is the perception of sound in the absence of acoustic stimulation, which is mainly 41 
associated with hearing loss. On the other hand, hyperacusis is the increased sensitivity to the 42 
sounds, which results in pain or the sufferers feeling uncomfortable and related to the intensity. 43 
Phonophobia has been defined as the fear of sounds used by patients expressing fear of certain 44 
sounds due to abnormal limbic and autonomic nervous system activation. However, misopho nia 45 
is distinct from these disorders, although there is some overlap in symptoms, and an individual 46 
may present with more than one condition ( Jastreboff., 2001; Swedo et al., 2022) . Szczepek et al. 47 
(2022)  have also reported that misophonia can occur with and without an average hearing threshold 48 
and alone or with other auditory conditions such as tinnitus and hyperacusis.  Misophonia is 49 
relatively less explored in  the field of audiology.  50 
The exact pathophysiology of misophonia is not known yet. Various neuro physiological 51 
studies have shown hyperactivation of the auditory pathway in individuals with misophonia 52 
(Kumar et al., 2017) . Audiologists are professionals trained to deal with sound and related auditory 53 
disorders. The various treatment approaches trialed  in the literature for managing misophonia, such 54 
as Tinnitus retraining therapy (TRT) and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), fall in the 55 
Journal Pre-proof

audiology domain. Jastreboff & Jastreboff ( 2002)  reported that tinnitus -retraining therapy should 56 
work better with mi sophonia patients than with tinnitus patients because misophonia involves an 57 
external trigger, which can be manipulated to potentially eliminate the conditioned response. 58 
Reclassifying the trigger sounds and extensive counseling are recommended for individ uals with 59 
misophonia. Jastreboff ( 2015)  reported the effectiveness of tinnitus retraining therapy in 60 
misophonia patients with and without hyperacusis.  61 
Besides tinnitus retraining therapy, Cognitive -Relaxation Coping Skills Training and 62 
Multicomponent Cog nitive -Behavioral Therapy (CBT) have also been used to treat misophonia 63 
(McGuire et al., 2015)  successfully. Few case reports have been published showing CBT's 64 
effectiveness for clients with misophonia. In the study by Schröder et al. (2017) , 48% of the 65 
participants improved after the eight sessions of CBT on the Clinical global improvement scale. 66 
Similarly, Bernstein et al. (2013)  reported improved social and occupational functioning after the 67 
six sessions of CBT in patients with misophonia.  68 
The assessment  and management of misophonia need a team approach, including a 69 
Neurologist, Audiologist, Psychologist, and Occupational therapists. Audiologists are vital 70 
members of the team. However, the role of an audiologist in this condition is not well understood, 71 
and there is a lack of awareness even among professionals about their role in the assessment and 72 
management of misophonia. The information regarding epidemiology, etiology, pathophysiology, 73 
and co -morbid conditions of misophonia remains unknown, especially in developing countries like 74 
India.  75 
Misophonia is  not studied from an audiological perspective , and most professionals are 76 
unaware of this disorder. In developing countries like India, most audiologists do not consider 77 
misophonia as  an auditory disorder, and they should conduct separate assessment and management 78 
protocols for individuals with misophonia. The assessment and management protocols that the 79 
audiologist uses for tinnitus and hyperacusis may not work for misophonia as the 80 
pathophysiological mecha nism behind the disorder is different. Hence, there is an immense need 81 
to create awareness about misophonia assessment and management among audiologists 82 
worldwide, especially in developing countries like India.  83 
The primary aim of our study is to study the status of misophonia assessment and 84 
management in various hearing healthcare set up in India. In addition, our study also documents 85 
Journal Pre-proof

the present level of awareness about the assessment and management of misophoni a among 86 
audiologists in India which can further be used to spread awareness about misophonia among 87 
professionals as well as among the general public. In India, no such investigation has been 88 
conducted till now. This will be the first study of its kind. It will be instrumental in creating 89 
awareness among professionals regarding the role of audiologists in misophonia and motivating 90 
professionals to develop assessment and management protocols for help ing individuals with 91 
misophonia disorder.  92 
METHODS  93 
Ethical Guidelines  94 
Ethical guidelines formulated by the institutional review board were followed for the study. The 95 
ethical approva l number was SH/ERB/2022 -22/36. Informed consent was taken from all the 96 
participants in the form of a question in the google form.  97 
 98 
Participants  99 
A descriptive cross -sectional study was conducted among audiologists all over India over three 100 
months, from April 2022 to July 2022. A questionnaire designed for the study was distributed to 101 
the 500 working audiologist in different hearing car e set up via online survey modes such as Gmail, 102 
whats' app, and LinkedIn. Among the 500 audiologists, 190 from different geographic areas of 103 
India responded to the survey.  104 
Inclusive and Exclusive Criteria  105 
All the audiologists working in the hearing care se tup having the minimum qualification of 106 
Bachelor in Speech -language pathology and Audiology (BASLP) with RCI registration are 107 
included in the survey. Professionals with BASLP degrees but working as speech -language 108 
pathologists, professionals working as hea ring specialists with a diploma degree, and all speech - 109 
language pathologists have been excluded from the survey. There was no age limit for responding 110 
to the survey. The participants who were  not Indian  citizens  were excluded from the study.  All the 111 
partic ipants were well educated with good English language competency to respond to the survey.  112 
Design of the Questionnaires  113 
Journal Pre-proof

A survey questionnaire was prepared in Google regarding the awareness of assessment and 114 
management of misophonia. The authors formulated 23 closed -set and open -set questions in the 115 
English language based on their experience regarding the assessment and management of 116 
misophonia and the basis of a literature review. Out of 23 questions, eight were related to 117 
demographic details, qualification s, and experience in audiology. Similarly, ten questions were 118 
related to awareness and the audiologist's perspectives on the assessment of misophonia, and five 119 
were related to perspectives regarding misophonia management.  120 
The questionnaires were given to f ive audiologists for validation. The construct validity was done 121 
by using a five -point rating scale. For each question, five correspond to the most worthy questions, 122 
and one corresponds to the least worthy questions. All the 23 questions included in the surve y were 123 
rated as 4 or 5 on the Likert scale and considered for the study.  124 
Among 23 questions, 21 were closed set with the multiple choice option. In contrast, two were 125 
open -set questions where audiologists had to answer their perspectives and ideas on the a ssessment 126 
and management of misophonia (provided as supplementary material).  127 
Procedure  128 
The contact details, including the email address and phone numbers of all the working audiologists, 129 
were taken from the concerned institute and the Indian speech and hea ring association (ISHA) 130 
dictionary. The questionnaires were mailed to the 500 working audiologists in different geographic 131 
areas of India. Among 500 emails, we got a response from 118 audiologists. The telephonic 132 
interview was done for the audiologists who  did not respond to the emails. Seventy -two 133 
audiologists responded to our phone call and answered the questions. Overall, 190 audiologists 134 
responded to our survey. All the data collection procedure was done after taking informed consent 135 
from the profession als. 136 
Statistical Analysis  137 
The response to the questionnaires was tracked in the spreadsheet in Microsoft Excel 2010. The 138 
investigator analyzed the response to the questionnaire and converted it into numerical form. 139 
Obtained data were analyzed using a stati stical package of social science (SPSS Version 25.) 140 
software. Descriptive statistical procedures such as frequency and percentages were measured 141 
based on the type of questions being addressed. As the data were descriptive and did not follow 142 
Journal Pre-proof

the normality, a non -parametric c hi-square test was done to see the association between the 143 
variables.  144 
 145 
RESULTS  146 
Demographic characteristics  147 
Among 190 audiologists who responded to the survey, 71 (37.36%) were male, and 119 (62.63%) 148 
were female. All participants' mean age  was 35.7 years (SD=8.8 years). All the participants worked 149 
as audiologists with a minimum qualification of an undergraduate bachelor's in audiology and 150 
speech -language pathology. Out of 190 participants, 51 (26.85%) participants have done 151 
undergraduate in  audiology, and speech -language pathology, 134 (70.52%) have done post - 152 
graduation in audiology, and 5 (2.63%) have done Ph.D. in audiology. All the audiologists 153 
included in the study worked in audiology with a minimum experience of 2 years and a maximum 154 
of 15 years (Mean= 7year, SD= 6 years). Most participants, 102 (53.68%), reported working as an 155 
audiologist in an academic institute, followed by hospital set up 52 (27.37%) and private practice 156 
36 (18.95%).  157 
Awareness about misophonia  158 
Among 190 audiologists,  who responded to the survey, 175 (92.10%) reported they are aware of 159 
the terminology, 7(3.68%) reported they are not clear about the term misophonia, and 8 (4.21%) 160 
reported they are not even aware of the terminology. Even though many audiologists reported  that 161 
they are aware of the terminology, only a few audiologists, 29(15.3%), reported being confident 162 
in handling cases with misophonia using audiological approaches. The detailed awareness of 163

The question was asked regarding the audiologist's perspectives on the misophonia domain and 167 
the cause of the misophonia. Out of 190 audiologists, 55(28.95%) categorize misophonia as an 168 
auditory disorder, 35 (18.42%) categorize it as a psychiatric disorder, and 14 (7.6%) as a 169

misophonia. The rest of the audiologists categorize Misophonia into tw o or three domains: 171

Audiologist Perspectives on assessment of misophonia  181 
Audiologists were asked about the number of cases of misophonia they get in their work facility. 182 
Out of 190 audiologists, only 25 (13.15%) reported cases of miso phonia in their workplace, with 183 
an enrollment of 10 -50 cases per year. The other 165 (86.84%) reported no cases of misophonia at 184 
their workplace. The questions were asked regarding their perspectives on the diagnosis of 185 
misophonia from tinnitus and hyperac usis. Most of the audiologist, 129(67.89%), reported that 186 
diagnostic protocols for misophonia differs from other sound disorders such as tinnitus and 187 
hyperacusis, 45 (23.7%) reported they are not sure about the diagnostic protocols of misophonia, 188 
and 16(8. 5%) reported that diagnostic protocols of misophonia are similar as tinnitus and 189 
hyperacusis.  190 
Audiologists' perspectives regarding the best diagnostic protocol for individuals with 191 
misophonia were asked. Most of the audiologists, 56 (29.47%), answered tha t a combined 192

that can be used to assess misophonia from the audiological perspective. Among 190 audiologists, 197

Audiologist Perspectives on the management of misophonia  205 
The audiologist perspectives on the importance of a multidisciplinary team approach in managing 206 
misophonia were assessed, and most audiologists 182 (95.79%) reported the need for a team 207 
approach to managing misophonia . Most participants, 103 (54.21%), reported that misophonia 208 
management differs from tinnitus and hyperacusis. However, 63(33.16%) audiologists reported 209 
they were not sure about the management of misophonia, and 24 (12.63%) audiologist s reported 210 
no differences in the management protocol of misophonia from tinnitus and hyperacusis.  211 
Questions were asked regarding the professionals managing misophonia at their work facility. 212 
More than half of the audiologists, 96 (50.53%), mentioned that a udiologists, psychologists, and 213 
Neurologists are the primary team members in managing misophonia at their workplace. Besides 214 
these team members, a few audiologists mentioned that ENT specialists and occupational 215 
therapists are also involved in the manageme nt program. The detailed response from all the 216 
audiologists is shown in Table 3.   217 
Audiologists' perspectives on misophonia management were assessed by asking an open - 218 
ended question about the approaches that can be used to manage misophonia from the audiolo gical 219 
domain. Among 190 audiologists, 118 (62.1%) audiologists responded to that open -ended 220 
question. Most audiologists suggested trials with multiple approaches would be suitable for 221 
managing misophonia as the efficacy of approaches varies from individual  to individual. The 222 
majority of the audiologists suggested cognitive behavioral therapy (79.66%), tinnitus retraining 223 
therapy (70.33%), desensitization therapy (60.16%), and counseling (60.16%) to be the effective 224

Need for Research on misophonia  228 
Audiologists' viewpoint on the need for Research on misophonia was assessed on a three - 229 
point rating scale. The result  showed that 162(85.26%) of the audiologist agreed on the fact that 230 
there is a lack of Research on misophonia from the audiological perspective, and 13(6.8%) of the 231 
audiologist rated neutral about the lack of Research, which would suggest they are not awar e of 232

Association between education qualification and misophonia case handling skills  235

DISCUSSION  243 
Misophonia is the most commonly occurring disorder with a high prevalence rate (Zhou et 244 
al., 2017) . Although the accurate assessment and management of m isophonia is still the topic of 245 
debate, it is clear that audiologists are the team's key members, and it falls in the audiology domain. 246 
Wu et al. (2014) conducted a study involving a sample of 483 US college students using an online 247 
questionnaire, which re vealed a prevalence of misophonia at 19.9%. Similarly, a recent study by 248 
Naylor et al. (2021)  reported clinically significant misophonia in 49.1% of the study sample 249 
population among the U.K. undergraduate medical student population. These data showed 250 
Journal Pre-proof

Prevalence of misophonia is increasing with time. However, in our study, 86.84% of audiologists 251 
reported no cases of misophonia at their workplace. This result showed that audiologists are not 252 
considered team members in the assessment and management of misopho nia in India, and there is 253 
a lack of referrals to audiologists'. Hence, it is essential to create awareness about the roles of an 254 
audiologist in the assessment and management of misophonia among professionals as well for the 255 
better intervention of patients  with misophonia from all possible perspectives.  256 
  Our study aimed to study the present level of awareness about misophonia among working 257 
audiologists all over India.  The study by Porcaro & Danesh. ( 2019)  reported a lack of awareness 258 
about misophonia disorder among academi cs. Similar to their findings, our study also  showed a 259 
lack of awareness and confidence in the assessment and management of misophonia among 260 
audiologists in India. Misophonia is a disorder  that can occur in isolation or association with other 261 
sound disorders, such as tinnitus and hyperacusis ( Jastreboff & Jastreboff., 2002) . It is necessary 262 
to differentiate misophonia from tinnitus and hyperacusis, as this is a separate entity with different 263 
neurophysiological mechani sms behind them. With time, awareness about hyperacusis and tinnitus 264 
is increasing among audiologists, and many cases are diagnosed and treated appropriately in the 265 
audiology clinic. However, misophonia is lagging, and audiologists have made no effort to 266 
understand this disorder and the inclusion of the disorder in the audiology domain.  267 
One possible reason for this problem could be the lack of misophonia education in India's 268 
undergraduate and post -graduation syllabus. Tinnitus and hyperacusis are included as separate 269 
disorders in the syllabus of masters of audiology, but misophonia/phonophobia are not included. 270 
Hence, it is essential to include misophonia education in the education syllabus of the universities 271 
to educate the students about misopho nia in det ail, which could help to expand the field of 272 
audiology.  273 
Misophonia is a challenging topic t o study and a challenging disorder  to diagnose and treat. 274 
The exact etiology and neurophysiological mechanism behind it have not been proven yet. The 275 
result of our s tudy showed that 34.74% of audiologists included in the study believed that the 276 
misophonia's etiology could be either neurophysiological or psychological. However, no studies 277 
are reported in the literature from the audiological perspective to know about th e physiological 278 
mechanism of misophonia using audiological test batteries. The lack of Research on misophonia 279 
Journal Pre-proof

from the audiological perspective could either be due to the lack of knowledge about misophonia 280 
among audiologists or the lack of misophonia cases  getting referred to audiology clinics.  281 
Patients with misophonia are unaware of the professionals involved in diagnosing and 282 
managing their condition as there is a lack of awareness among the general public, especially in 283 
developing countries like India. Therefore, it is the professionals' role to make appropriate referrals 284 
to the concerned professionals. Hence, it is essential to spread knowledge about misophonia among 285 
the general public and professionals so that the patient with it would get appropriate treatment 286 
from the concerned professionals.  287 
The assessment and management of misophonia are not known yet. Especially from the 288 
audiological domain, much less work has been done to assess and manage misophonia. The result 289 
of our study showed that most audio logists believed the tests batteries approach, including pure 290 
tone audiometry, UCL testing, and electrophysiological tests, would be appropriate for the 291 
assessment of misophonia. In the patients with misophonia, Jastreboff (2013)   reported. Loudness 292 
discom fort level (LDL) may be average or at a reduced level. Similarly,  Jager et al.(2020)  have 293 
reported that misophonia can occur with and without an average hearing threshold through the 294 
administration of pure tone audiometry (PTA) in a few subjects with miso phonia. However, there 295 
are no studies done in the literature using test batteries, including both behavioral and 296 
electrophysiological measures. Hence, these data showed a need to conduct a study on misophonia 297 
using the test batteries from the audiology dom ain to come to the effective conclusion.  298 
The result of the audiologist's perspectives regarding the management of misophonia 299 
showed that most audiologists believed that audiological approaches such as cognitive behavioral 300 
therapy, retraining therapy, desensitization therapy, and counseling could help manage 301 
misophonia. However, very few experimental studies are done in the literature to know the efficacy 302 
of these treatment approaches. Few case reports have been published showing CBT's effectiveness 303 
for clients with misophonia. In the study by Eijsker et al. (2017) , 48% of the participants improved 304 
after the eight sessions of CBT on the Clinical global improvement scale. Similarly, Jastreboff & 305 
Jastreboff ( 2002)  reported that retraining therapy should work better with misophonia patients 306 
than with tinnitus patients because misophonia involves an external trigger, which can be 307 
manipulated to potentially eliminate the conditioned response. Hence, it is the role of audiologists 308 
Journal Pre-proof

to explore the efficacy of these audiological treatment approaches in the f uture for patients with 309 
misophonia.  310 
 311 
CONCLUSION AND LIMITATION OF THE STUDY  312 
Our study concludes that many audiologists are unaware of their role in the assessment and 313 
management of misophonia  all over India. Audiologists need to be aware of their role in patients 314 
with misophonia, and they should be active members of the team to understand misophonia from 315 
different perspectives. Team -based diagnosis and management protocol, including an audiologist 316 
as the team member, is very much necessary for assessing an d treating an individual with 317 
misophonia. Hence, it is necessary to spread awareness among team members for the appropriate 318 
referral to the concerned professionals as per the need of the patients. Treatment should be 319 
individualized depending on the co -morb id condition and its severity. Depending on the severity, 320 
associated conditions, and the client's need, the team members' role needs should be highlighted. 321 
Hence, we strongly highlight that audiologist needs to be an active team member to assess and 322 
manage  misophonia, which is lacking in the current scenario. There is also a need to spread 323 
awareness about the role of audiologists among the general public and the team members. Our 324 
study could not assess team members' perspectives, such as psychologists and n eurologists, 325 
regarding the role of audiologists in the assessment and management of misophonia. This type of 326 
study is necessary to conduct in the future to know about their viewpoint on the audiologist's 327 
role, which could help to create awareness among the  professionals about the role of audiologists 328 
in misophonia.  329
